addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

4 Martij
1594
M
r
Bodeleie to my L. A third l
re
intercepted./

page.lettertext:
fol.90r
May it please yo
r
good L. Among divers l
re
s sent
from
Brussels,
and intercepted heere of late, I sent
yow two w
t
my last of
e 26 of Fe
b
and heerew
t
a third, w
ch
was also written by
e same
Crytten
to
James Tyrius
e Scottishe Jesuit at
Rome,
and did
not seeme to be regarded by those
at kept
e l
re
s.
But I finde it worth
e reading for many respectes,
because it doth manifest
at there are many brabbles
and discontentm
ts
among those of
at nation in Brussels
and els where: and
at they are in despaire of good suc-
cesse in
e Enemies actions both heere and in
france.
It is also easie to perceave by perusing
e wordes
interlaced, w
t
e figures,
at there is mater there signi-
fied of special importance: w
ch
if it can not be deci-
phred by any at home, I am of opinion,
at a copie
of
e l
re
being sent to some man
at is of capacitie,
and imploied by yo
r
L. in Brussels or
Andwerp,
if he
be
but acquainted w
t
e Scottes
at are there, and
e factious among them, it will be p
nt
ly discovered.
These
at are heere of
e Scottishe nation, for want of know-
lege, who they are
at are there, and howe they stand
for affection one to an other, can give me no light.
As touching my negotiation,
e returne of
e Deputies
of
Guelders
and
Overysel
are daily nowe expected,
and then
e states, I am certaine, will deliver me their
answear, w
t
out putting me of to a further day.
We have assured intelligence from divers places of
e Enemies contreis,
at
e vulgar people every where
crie openly out against their miseries, shewing manifest
token
at they desire to be joined to
e rest of this union.
And as farre as I can judge of
e states inclinatio,
if
e motion proceede from
e other side to them,
fol.90v
thereafter as it is, they are fully bent to intertaine it,
to
e best advant age of their cause. But whether it
were expedient,
at we should strike at this iron, while
it is hotte, and be
e first
at should send to
e Enemies
Provinces,
at doth rest in deliberation: albeit I doe
perceave
at most men are of mind,
at we should not
sturre in this case, but as occasions are p
nt
ed from them
unto us. For this is alleaged for it, That before they
send to
e Enemie, in a mater of
at importance, they
must first of force heere at home have recourse to every
Province, to purchase autoritie, whereby it will be impar-
ted to every towne, and so come abroade among
e people,
who, as every man doubtes, may prove so every hedlonge
in suche a plausible motion, as perhaps when they see
it is once sette a foote, they will violently thorowe, w
t
out
regard to their owne securitie. The feare of this hu-
mor in
e multitude, doth stay them from proceeding
as they are otherwise willing. It is comonly
reported
at
e Enemie prepareth for
e siege of
Huy,
w
ch
he will finde a very hotte and a costly exploit.
For
Haurangieres
e commaunder is a valiant expert
souldier, and will undoubtedly perfourme as muche as
can be required.
And thus I take my h
u
ble leave.
From
e Hage. Ma
r
4 1594.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
